questions.question_text:
A company uses AWS CloudFormation to deploy its application infrastructure. Recently, a user accidentally changed a property of a database in a CloudFormation template and performed a stack update that caused an interruption to the application. A SysOps administrator must determine how to modify the deployment process to allow the DevOps team to continue to deploy the infrastructure, but prevent against accidental modifications to specific resources.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

choices.D: Attach an IAM policy to the DevOps team role that prevents a CloudFormation stack from updating, with a condition based on the specific Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of the protected resources.
choices.B: Set up an Amazon EventBridge event with a rule to initiate based on any CloudFormation API call. An AWS Lambda function can then describe the stack to determine if any protected resources were modified and cancel the operation.
choices.A: Set up an AWS Config rule to alert based on changes to any CloudFormation stack. An AWS Lambda function can then describe the stack to determine if any protected resources were modified and cancel the operation.
choices.C: Launch the CloudFormation templates using a stack policy with an explicit allow for all resources and an explicit deny of the protected resources with an action of Update:*.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Stack Policy:

Define a stack policy for the CloudFormation stack containing your application infrastructure.
In the policy, use an explicit Deny statement for any update actions (Update*) on the specific resources you want to protect (e.g., critical databases, security groups).

choices.C: The template did not have the proper level of permissions to deploy the resources.
choices.D: The template requested services that do not exist in eu-west-1.
choices.E: CloudFormation templates can be used only to update existing services.
choices.A: The template referenced an IAM user that is not available in eu-west-1.
choices.B: The template referenced an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) that is not available in eu-west-1.

discussion.content:
Since it's another region in the same account, and roles are global:
C is wrong.

Selected Answer: BD
I will go with BD as well.

A SysOps administrator has an AWS CloudFormation template of the company's existing infrastructure in us-west-2. The administrator attempts to use the template to launch a new stack in eu-west-1, but the stack only partially deploys, receives an error message, and then rolls back.

Why would this template fail to deploy? (Choose two.)

An application accesses data through a file system interface. The application runs on Amazon EC2 instances in multiple Availability Zones, all of which must share the same data. While the amount of data is currently small, the company anticipates that it will grow to tens of terabytes over the lifetime of the application.

What is the MOST scalable storage solution to fulfill this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I vote C 
In this situation we can not used mount-target because we have multiple Availability.
As reported in the document below :
"You can create one mount target in each Availability Zone in your VPC. All EC2 instances in a VPC within a given Availability Zone share a single mount target for a given file system. If you have multiple subnets in an Availability Zone, you create a mount target in one of the subnets. EC2 instances do not need to be in the same subnet as the mount target in order to access their file system.You can create only one mount target for a One Zone file system. You must create that mount target in the same Availability Zone in which the file system is located."
The instances have to share to the EFS in mulitiple Availability Zone so for me is need use the NFS.
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/cli/latest/reference/efs/create-mount-target.html

Selected Answer: B
EFS the best option here.

Selected Answer: B
I agree with B

choices.B: Deploy Amazon EFS in the VPC and create mount targets in multiple subnets.
choices.C: Launch an EC2 instance and share data using SMB/CIFS or NFS.
choices.A: Connect a large Amazon EBS volume to multiple instances and schedule snapshots.
choices.D: Deploy an AWS Storage Gateway cached volume on Amazon EC2.

questions.question_text:
A company is deploying an ecommerce application to an AWS Region that is located in France. The company wants users from only France to be able to access the first version of the application. The company plans to add more countries for the next version of the application. A SysOps administrator needs to configure the routing policy in Amazon Route 53.

Which solution will meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Tips:
Geolocation = location of users 
Geoproximity = location of resources

Selected Answer: B
Agree with B

answer B
Geolocation routing enables customers to choose the resources that serve their traffic based on the geographic location of their users. Customers can use this feature to localize content or restrict distribution of content to only the locations for which they have distribution rights.

https://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2022/03/amazon-route-53-launches-geolocation-latency-based-routing-private-dns/#:~:text=Geolocation%20routing%20enables%20customers%20to,which%20they%20have%20distribution%20rights.

choices.D: Use a geoproximity routing policy. Select all IP addresses that are allocated to France in the record.
choices.C: Use an IP-based routing policy. Select all IP addresses that are allocated to France in the record.
choices.B: Use a geolocation routing policy. Select France as the location in the record.
choices.A: Use a geoproximity routing policy. Select France as the location in the record.
